trans:
In fact, the English economist Angus Maddison, in a study that takes into account two thousand years of world economic history, identifies the 11th century as the turning point that marked Europe’s rise over the rest of the world and simultaneously generated the deep inequalities among continents, some of which persist to this day.
The European history of the Christian era is therefore characterized by three phases which we will analyze one by one:
a positive first phase, from the 1st to the 3rd century, marked by the development of long-distance trade, the centrality of the Mediterranean, economic prosperity, and stability guaranteed by the Roman Empire.
a negative second phase, from the 4th to the 10th century, marked by political crises, the division of the Roman Empire and the end of the Western Empire, by significant migratory flows of barbarian populations, the failure of centralized political systems, the stagnation of trade and monetary circulation, and a closed economy limited to
local level.
A positive third phase, from the 11th to the 19th century, fin which there is strong economic growth for Western Europe, which expanded its commercial horizons to the Far East and, after the 15th century, across the ocean; the development of an urban and bourgeois culture committed to the pursuit of profit, political changes aimed at building nation states.
